What did you make, Forrest Stith, of the comments by Reverend Obama that his greatest complaint with what Reverend Wright had to say was that it put it - it seems as if he was saying this is a situation where there had been no progress?
I don't think that.
I think that Jeremiah Wright, if you listen to his sermons - and I've heard many of them - are outstanding and powerful, but he takes the step further.
He does call for reconciliation and he does call for a reunion of faith and salvation, and he gives people the positive approach.
But he does speak truth to power, and you cannot solve any issue that needs reconciliation unless you speak truth.
It's how you speak the truth.
And I would say that it's old- time rhetoric.
We need a new civil rights movement.
We need a new take on this thing.
We need to help the people who are embracing the need for change - whites and Hispanics and others - and encourage them with our language.

And when we have a national platform where people are taping your words, presenting them to the whole nation, we need to be aware that we're no longer are street- corner preachers or in a kaffeeklatsch just talking among ourselves.
Our words have power.
In that way, it was irresponsible what Jeremiah Wright has said and how he said it.
And have you both considered that these excerpts from sermons or these tiny little clips of...
Right.

...the one of thousands of sermons of the Reverend Wright has to deliver over decades, these are going to be a feature of the presidential campaign should Senator Obama get the nomination on the Democratic side.
There could be television advertisements with the - do you worry about this kind of exposure?
I worry about it because I think it's demonstrative of what - of persons who want to defeat him or persons of color anytime they look for an excuse.
If they really want to understand Jeremiah Wright, they could do that, but they don't.

They're looking for little bits of information, which were done not only in a context of a local church worship, but in a context of a setting of African-American and others who were present that were in a different kind of a context and setting.
And people will take advantage of that, but you can't do a thing about it.

White-led church in America typically deals with righteousness issues, how do people relate to God.
And the black-led church has dealt with some social justice issues because we've been oppressed.
But the Bible teaches that righteousness and justice together are the foundation of God's throne.
In other words, the complete gospel has righteousness issues and justice issues.
And what I'm advocating - I think what the caller means is that there needs to be this balanced approach to both.
It should not be that Jeremiah Wright is the only one talking about social justice.
And in some ways, it's the failure of preaching the whole gospel for the whole man that has given place for liberation theology and maybe the necessity for it.

And what I'm advocating is that everybody, black- and white-led churches alike, Hispanic and others would begin to preach a more balanced gospel with righteousness and justice being the heart of what we declare in our generation.
